ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the postulates of quantum mechanics and how to apply them to predict the result of measuring a quantum state and to determine how a quantum state evolves over time. I became accustomed to thinking of wave functions as elements of an infinite-dimensional Hilbert space. I began to recognize deep connections between quantum and classical mechanics.
Basic knowledge of some of the principles of quantum physics, including analysis of some special cases.

Basics of the QM formalism, some toy examples (e.g. particle in a box, harmonic oscillator, etc.), some discussion of scattering and many-body dynamics (e.g. bosons & fermions), and a somewhat analog discussion of symmetries (i.e. momentum is the generator of translations; no representation theory). Emphasis was definitely on being able to solve textbook QM problems.
Learned great skills of how to apply math to physics problems especially linear algebra in infinite dimensions.
Quantum mechanics, Hilbert spaces, the postulates, scattering, harmonic oscillator, identical particles, symmetries and conservation laws, etc.
Basic introduction to quantum mechanics. Learned a bit of classical mechanics, saw where it failed, and saw where quantum mechanics picked up.
An introduction to quantum mechanics
We learned how to do a good number of different classic quantum problems.
We covered linear algebra first, then the postulates of quantum mechanics and some types of potentials and symmetries.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: One strength of this course is that the material is presented with the mathematical background at the beginning, so everyone is on the same page in terms of understanding the mathematics of quantum mechanics. The course is also the first part in a two-course sequence, so the material doesn't feel too rushed. I honestly cannot think of any weaknesses of this course.

The material of the course is interesting, and the parts of the course which actually emphasized new theory (i.e. the lecture on symmetries and conservation laws) could be emphasized and expanded.

The course spends an inordinate amount of time on review of basic mathematics, beginning without even an assumption of vector algebra. Moreover, it spends additional time reviewing the definition of the classical Lagrangian and Hamiltonian, material covered in the listed prerequisite course. In short, the course needs to be much faster. A greater emphasis on the theoretical aspects of the concepts at play, rather than simple equation-solving, would also be greatly appreciated.

Not very engaging, too many psets, psets too long. Lots of non-trivial mathematical details glossed over but we were expected to just know.? Example recent on my mind is derivatives of operators wrt scalars/vectors/operators, which came up a lot but were not addressed 

Only got like 3/13 psets grades back by end of semester

Strengths- TAs, course notes, and the textbook
Weaknesses- Lectures and recorded lectures were a waste of time, but the course notes were very informative.

Prof. Shankar's recorded lectures were near incomprehensible; very little structure, difficult to follow, and left me with little more than vague intuitions. His live Zoom lectures were far better, since he would share notes on the screen that we could follow as he was talking. That said, most of my learning in this course came from struggling with the material on my own. Pset problems could sometimes be tricky, and not directly follow from what we had learned in class, but the TA was very helpful and Prof. Shankar was always available for emailed questions. Tests were easier than psets for the most part, though it's strange that they aren't open book, or that we weren't at least allowed to bring our own formula sheet. In general, this course could really benefit from more structure.
Perhaps live portion could be more different than pre recorded lectures.

Strengths: professor was very available to answer questions, the format this year basically had us hearing everything twice which helped solidify it

Weaknesses: very slow grading, it would have been really helpful to have had clear and consistent feedback. Only like 2/13 psets were graded before the final

We only got grades for 3 problem sets before the end of the year so more feedback would have been nice. Shankar is a good professor and does care about our learning but every once in a while assumes some odd prior knowledge.

Strength: the lecture learning goals sheets were useful for solving problems and studying for exams. Strength: having practice questions during the live portion of the class was helpful in evaluating my understanding.

Having multiple sources from which to learn was good (recorded and live lectures and posted learning goals). The class topics were covered rigorously. The live lectures, however, were hard to follow often especially since there wasn't much drawing or writing to go along with reading the learning goals.

Most of class was just reading through a posted notes PDF, so that wasnt that engaging. Also very little is explained thoroughly and the textbook doesnt help much either, and then the homework is ridiculously hard and usually makes you feel like youve learned nothing. The tests are reasonable, though, and the professor made class feel pretty relaxed.

strengths: the course is well organized, and the instructor is very knowledgeable about the subject. The typed learning goals for each lecture is a brilliant idea. I benefited a lot from them.
weakness: the hw and exam grading is slow. I hope I can get feedback sooner.
Professor Shankar's dedication to answering questions for the students was very helpful for the course. It would have been better with more (and more regular) office hours.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prerecorded lectures are actually very helpful -- they allow students to progress at their own pace.
Having to watch recorded lectures before class was burdensome
The recorded lectures prior to class were helpful prior to class.
I think having the final be worth 40% of our grade during the pandemic was annoying. I think homework should've counted for a lot more than it did.
Pre recorded lectures were a good strategy
The prerecorded online lectures were nice but watching an hour of lecture before our synchronous lectures was quite a bit of work.
Multiple sources to learn from (especially recorded lectures).

Professor Shankar's willingness to meet on Zoom at different times outside of class was very helpful. It was also successful to record the lectures and have practice questions during the videos to stay engaged. The repetition from the lecture recaps really helped us understand the material. Sometimes Canvas assignments weren't posted early enough, but this was easily rectified with an email to the TAs.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to another student with sufficient mathematical background, whether a physics major or not. Shankar is a must-have professor and quantum is a cool way to think about the world.
No, there was absolutely no feedback throughout the course besides the midterm grades. So problem set comments were posted and only grades for 3 of the 12? 13? problem sets were posted at all.
I would recommend because the material is interesting not because the class itself was good. I think the required lectures before class were wildly unhelpful, but the course notes were great.

This was my first physics course at Yale, having primarily done math beforehand (which I thought would be mostly enough). It turned out to be very difficult for me to follow. I wouldn't recommend this course as a math elective. (There was obviously little in the way of derivations or proofs, but the ideas we learned didn't even seem to logically progress from each other, and a lot of it became memorization. Maybe this is just the nature of QM, but I'd like to imagine that there would be a more formal way to teach some of this subject. From what I've heard, the grad QM class seems to be a bit more along these lines.) I think that it was much better for physics majors, though.
Do not be afraid if you are not a physics major to take it. Very great class to take no matter what kind of applied math you like.
Yes for physics majors, but i know some non-majors who liked it
This is a great course to learn the basics of quantum mechanics if you have an interest in going into physics and want to see how classical mechanics fails.
Yes, the topic itself is very interesting and it's presented well.
If a math major needs an advanced science credit, maybe, but its not that fun
Yes, very important topic if you are a physics major and a lot of fun.

I would recommend this course. It is important to put aside your pride and ask questions to get the full learning experience. It is also important to form a study group. The format of lectures is very helpful, and there are abundant materials to review from.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual problem sessions/review of recordings also provided.
Recorded lectures to watch before class, then professor would recap the lectures in class
There were pre recorded lectures prior to class.
Combination of recorded lectures and virtual lecture.
Pre-recorded lectures followed by discussion in class.
Watched recorded lectures, discussed further in class
Recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.
Recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
recorded lecture with live lecture recaps
